gah, a typo

"Steps 1 - 3 are "design time", steps 4-5 are "runtime" in the=
 traditional 
sense 
of the term;"

should read

"Steps 1 - 4 are "design t=
ime", steps 5-6 are "runtime" in the traditional 
sense of the term;"




_=
_______________________________
From: Stuart Charlton <stuartcharlton@yahoo=
.com>
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tue, February 22, 2011 10:03:4=
7 PM
Subject: [rest-discuss] design vs runtime in representations

  
An id=
ea that's been needling in my head for a while, just want to float it out 
=
there.  This likely has been discussed before and I've just missed the thre=
ad.

Suppose the following

1. you have a media type that describes how to =
interact with other resources. 

2. you have resource http://MetaA that des=
cribes how to interact with a 
hyperlinked resource, http://RealA. 

3.  Me=
taA's representation has defined a very long cache TTL (say, 3 months)

4. =
A user agent that GETs the representation MetaA,  caches the representation=
 
of MetaA, and prompts User 1 to manipulate MetaA's representation to conf=
igure 
integration of the user agent's overall application to representatio=
ns that may 
be transferred to/from RealA

5. This same user agent is lever=
aged by User 2 over many months to interact with 

RealA given the cached M=
etaA.

6. If MetaA's representation changes, the User 1 is notified by the =
user agent 
(via some undefined mechanism) to change its configuration so t=
hat User 2 can 
continue to interact with RealA.

Steps 1 - 3 are "design t=
ime",  steps 4-5 are "runtime" in the traditional sense 

of the term;
User=
 1 is a developer (or technical user)
User 2 is an automaton (i.e. client c=
ode of some sort)
Both MetaA and RealA's representations are part of the ap=
plication state (aka. 
its hypermedia workspace), but the origin server(s) =
have set different 
expectations on how long they can be cached (MetaA for =
a long time, RealA for a 
short time).

Or, if you're more concrete minded,=
 imagine:
- You write a scraping application that caches an HTML form to a =
stock quote 
service, which a developer then uses to generate URIs to GET a=
 stock quote 
price.   The application is smart enough to periodically GET =
the HTML form and 
can detect changes, but would require developer interven=
tion in some cases, such 

as if the required bound form field names change=
d.

My question:

How is this not RESTful? (in the sense of it not being re=
spectful of the 
constraints of the style and thus sacrificing some benefic=
ial properties like 
scalability, evolvability, etc.)

My proposition:

1. =
If this is not RESTful, we'll have to talk.

2. If this is RESTful, we need=
 to be really careful when we say there's no 
"design time" in RESTful syst=
ems. 

I think the clearer statement is that "static code generation" (e.g.=
 client 
stubs) is discouraged in properly RESTful systems, since it tends =
towards 
sucktacular rigidity in the user agent.

Cheers
Stu

      <p>An idea that's been needlin=
g in my head for a while, just want to float it out <br>
there.  This likel=
y has been discussed before and I've just missed the thread.<br>
<br>
Suppo=
se the following<br>
<br>
1. you have a media type that describes how to in=
teract with other resources.   <br>
<br>
2. you have resource <a rel=3D"nof=
ollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://MetaA">http://MetaA</a> that descri=
bes how to interact with a <br>
hyperlinked resource, <a rel=3D"nofollow" t=
arget=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://RealA.">http://RealA.</a>  <br>
<br>
3.  Me=
taA's representation has defined a very long cache TTL (say, 3 months)<br>
=
<br>
4. A user agent that GETs the representation MetaA,  caches the repres=
entation <br>
of MetaA, and prompts User 1 to manipulate MetaA's representa=
tion to configure <br>
integration of the user agent's overall application =
to representations that may <br>
be transferred to/from RealA<br>
<br>
5. T=
his same user agent is leveraged by User 2 over many months to interact wit=
h <br>
RealA given the cached MetaA.<br>
<br>
6. If MetaA's representation =
changes, the User 1 is notified by the user agent <br>
(via some undefined =
mechanism) to change its configuration so that User 2 can <br>
continue to =
interact with RealA.<br>
<br>
Steps 1 - 3 are "design time",  steps 4-5 are=
 "runtime" in the traditional sense <br>
of the term;<br>
User 1 is a devel=
oper (or technical user)<br>
User 2 is an automaton (i.e. client code of so=
me sort)<br>
Both MetaA and RealA's representations are part of the applica=
tion state (aka. <br>
its hypermedia workspace), but the origin server(s) h=
ave set different <br>
expectations on how long they can be cached (MetaA f=
or a long time, RealA for a <br>
short time).<br>
<br>
Or, if you're more c=
oncrete minded, imagine:<br>
- You write a scraping application that caches=
 an HTML form to a stock quote <br>
service, which a developer then uses to=
 generate URIs to GET a stock quote <br>
price.   The application is smart =
enough to periodically GET the HTML form and <br>
can detect changes, but w=
ould require developer intervention in some cases, such <br>
as if the requ=
ired bound form field names changed.<br>
<br>
My question:<br>
<br>
How is =
this not RESTful? (in the sense of it not being respectful of the <br>
cons=
traints of the style and thus sacrificing some beneficial properties like <=
br>
scalability, evolvability, etc.)<br>
  <br>
My proposition:<br>
<br>
1.=
 If this is not RESTful, we'll have to talk.<br>
<br>
2. If this is RESTful=
, we need to be really careful when we say there's no <br>
"design time" in=
 RESTful systems.  <br>
<br>
I think the clearer statement is that "static =
code generation" (e.g. client <br>
stubs) is discouraged in properly RESTfu=
l systems, since it tends towards <br>
sucktacular rigidity in the user age=
nt.<br>
<br>
Cheers<br>
Stu<br>
<br>
</p>
